DOC.HEAD: U.S. Invasion of Panama Nets Valuable Drug Data
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. drug agents have been poring over thousands of seized documents that are providing valuable intelligence on international drug trafficking, authorities said Tuesday. They said the information could be used against Panamanians under U.S. drug indictments, such as Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and his associate, Lt. Col. Luis del Cid, who has been arrested and taken to the United States. One windfall was the headquarters of Panama's Anti-Narcotics Special Force. U.S. soldiers stormed the headquarters Monday and detained three men after being tipped off by an informant, said U.S. Army Lt. Col. William Leszczynski, commander of the 3rd Battalion, 9th Infantry Regiment. Authorities reported finding rifles, shotguns, handguns and much ammunition as well as cocaine, marijuana, morphine and drug paraphernalia. Torture apparently was carried out in the same building. Leszczynski said his troops found ``electronic devices that could be hooked up to people for electric shocks.'' They found a room filled with immigration files of foreigners from more than two dozen countries, including Cuba, Nicaragua and Colombia. The files, in racks that reached the ceiling, contained detailed information on foreigners' entries and exits. Each file had a small photo of the subject. One Miami-based agent of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration who visited the white stucco house Tuesday said that at first glance, it seemed to be a legitimate anti-narcotics operation. ``What I find unusual is that these files were kept in a house,'' she said. ``I need to find out whose house this is, in whose name it's registered.'' She spoke on condition of anonymity. The files largely were from the 1960s through the 70s. ``It's good for us,'' the agent said. ``This tells me who's been in an out of the country. I already found some files of Colombian drug traffickers. So now I know they were here. Now I go for the more recent files.'' She would not say how many DEA agents came here, although she said it was far fewer than 20. The U.S. military has provided transport, communications and other support, she added. Three makeshift jails at the back of the house seemed to have been inhabited recently. A plastic container with urine stood in the corner of one cell, where the occupant had slept on a dirty mat and cardboard placed on the cement floor.
